title: Cat. 93  The Laundress: “La Blanchisseuse de la place Dauphine,” 1894
publication_title: The Lithographs of James McNeill Whistler: The Digital Edition
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body"> 931894Way: 58  
Levy: 89  
Transfer lithograph, drawn on fine-grained transfer paper  
Ink color: black  
Signature: printed butterfly, lower right on shop facade  
One state; image size: 230 × 157 mm  
Number of impressions listed by Way: 25  
Printer: Way  
Watermarks: 67–69, 88, 90, 135, 136, 138, 139  
Posthumous edition: 50 impressions printed by Goulding on 11 March 1904  
Posthumous watermarks: 16, 17, 50, 53–56, 219, 220, 276, 292, 293, 319  
Stone: erased in 1904  
Whistler-Way Letters: 101, 102, 104, 107, 138, 141; apps. II.3, II.4, III.2, III.3, III.4, V.1  
Selected Literature: Pennell (1897), p. 287; Way and Dennis (1903), p. 86; Duret (1904), p. 127  
Lifetime Exhibitions: London 1895–96 (no. 21, as The Blanchisseuse of the Place Dauphine); Chicago 1900b (no. 54, as The Laundress); New York 1901 (no. 151, as La Blanchisseuse de la Place Dauphine)

Whistler returned repeatedly to the shopfront theme in every medium he employed. For this lithograph he selected as his subject a simple laundry shop on the place Dauphine, located between the Palais de Justice and the Pont Neuf. The artist positioned himself squarely in front of the blanchisserie, not many steps from the open doorway through which four laundresses are depicted busily working; a fifth woman opens the shuttered windows above. A closely related Parisian etching entitled Blanchisserie (fig. 93a [K 438]) similarly portrays a sunny shop facade and the bustling activity in its dark interior.

Establishing the effect of chiaroscuro solely with line, Whistler was optimistic that this image would transfer and print successfully. When he wrote to T. R. Way on 7 August 1894, the day after mailing the transfer drawing to London, he noted that “it has no stump and ought to come out perfectly,” and he expressed his enthusiasm for “what I fancy is perhaps the best drawing I have done” (letter 101). Almost a year later, he still counted The Laundress among his best work in lithography. In a letter of 31 July 1895, he included the image among several that he wished T. R. Way to submit for inclusion in the British section of the “Centenaire de la lithographie” exhibition due to be held at the Champ de Mars in Paris from August to November of that year (letter 138).

Chicago: AIC, ivory laid paper (312 × 202 mm), signed; MWC, ivory laid paper (315 × 202 mm), signed. Glasgow: HAG (4), cream laid paper (314 × 204 mm), signed; cream laid paper (307 × 208 mm), signed; golden-yellow Japanese paper (308 × 189 mm), signed; cream laid paper (309 × 202 mm). London: BM, ivory laid paper (312 × 202 mm), inscribed, possibly in T. R. Way’s hand, The Laundress (Blanchisseuse de la Place Dauphine). Washington: FGA, cream laid paper (310 × 203 mm), signed; NGA, ivory laid paper (311 × 200 mm), signed

Remarks: Another impression is found in Cleveland, CMA.  
Nesta R. Spink, Harriet K. Stratis, Martha Tedeschi

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">In August 1894, however, Whistler wrote to Way that the image was “pale in chiaroscuro—I mean less rich than I would like”; letter 107.

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 93, only state. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of the Crown Family in honor of James N. Wood, 2004.614.

fig. 93a Blanchisserie, 1892–93 (K 438). Etching; 178 × 152 mm. Freer Gallery of Art, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D.C., 04.16.
